message: actually 'the' thing is that I end up more interested in learning how to do things then actually coding, like literally 1/2 the day yesterday :)
I think having a widescreen monitor is bad also, cuz then you put all this crap on the screen and it distracts me (not vim related but related to rants in general hehe)
personally, I hate that, because of its backwards-compatibility issues, there are some things you *just can't do*, so vim is destined to stay "ugly".

For example, there's a problem keeping a "file browser" pane open on the left of the screen, 'cause e.g. NERDTree is implemented as just another buffer.
You can't have things floating in the middle of the screen for "quick selection".
You can't have smaller fonts on some buffers, which really limits you in terms of things you can do.
Etc.
I think I need to make my font a tad bigger also, let me look that up now.
the NERDTRee misbehavior you mentioned is well handled in this startup configuration: https://github.com/carlhuda/janus

@convy So so true regarding your first post. I spend half-a-day every workday playing with Vim (see my other posts here, you'll see examples).

Regarding the widescreen distractions: Well, I use Vim on a seperate 'desktop' using my Mac's expose. This way Vim has it's own envorinment seperate from other distracting apps. You can also put it to fullscreen. No need for a these distraction-free text-editing apps.
